> I think a soldier or a barbarian would suit a god of war... I mean, 
 they're the ones who are _really_ associated with fighting...

Thanks.  I'm going to try to map out the entire set ahead of time.

As I've said before, I believe soldiers are mana guzzlers, but it may 
just be the stats I have.  I'll set up a test scenario to compare the 
barbarian and soldier in terms of damage per mana usage.

* * 

I went through all my hedge scenarios, the Port City, almost all of 
one path and I still run into the damn problem with my characters 
being killed in "Archer Encampment".  Worse yet, it's the same one who 
gets dying: the Archer.  I've spent a couple of fortunes improving the 
armor level, but to no result.

[I may redo Archer Encampment some more: put extra doors in place to 
slow down the rate of facing opponent teams and maybe widen some of 
those passages again so that I can use exploding bolt attack without 
hurting myself.]

What good is a super-strong character who can't take the hits?  It's 
utterly stupid that the opponent archers are strong enough to wipe 
each other out fairly easily.  (Personally, I like to keep armor 
levels pretty close to strength levels.  Also, high constitution 
levels make you more vulnerable to faerie attacks so forget 
self-healing.  Clerics aren't much good if you can be taken out in 1-2 
hits.)

The problem isn't my attacks aren't strong enough, but I run out of 
mana fairly quickly killing a lot of them in an area without killing 
all of them.  I'm concerned about raising the intelligence too high 
will in the long run be harmfull if the characters ever reach certain 
experience levels.

[All the same, I'm beginning to wonder if a 10 member team could, in 
fact, go through my own scenarios without running into constant 
problems.  If, in addition to the built-in scenarios, I had about 100 
more scenarios to set-up my team, completing the tevfifty afterwards 
would get me a team strong enough to complete my own scenarios. ]

It's also ridiculous that my cleric can raise a skeleton or a ghost 
with more health and mana than the cleric has.

It's annoying that my level 30+ druid can summon faeries that are only 
level 1.  Of course, the druid can't run out of mana growing trees 
because of the time delay between growing trees.
